PNEUMOCYSTIS JIROVECI IN A PATIENT WITH EARLY BREAST CANCER RECEIVING
PACLITAXEL

ALI AL SAFI KATHERINE ACOSTA AND HECTOR I OJEDA-MARTINEZ

INTRODUCTION: Pneumocystis jirovecii (PJP) is one of the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome-defining illnesses. However,
it can also occur in patients with malignant diseases, especially when they have been under treatment with chemotherapy,
immunosuppressive agents, or corticosteroids.

CASE PRESENTATION: A 57-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, cavitary pneumonia, and stage Ib invasive
intraductal carcinoma of the left breast. She had completed four cycles of dose-dense chemotherapy (DDC) with doxorubicin
and cyclophosphamide (AC) five months prior to admission, followed by paclitaxel and dexamethasone 10 mg
(approximately 70 mg of prednisone) weekly for 9 weeks. She presented to the hospital after she was found hypoxic prior to
chemotherapy infusion. On further questioning, she complained of exertional dyspnea, productive cough, and fatigue for
several weeks. On exam, she was tachycardic (HR 105 bpm), hypoxic SpO2 81% on room air, and bibasilar inspiratory
crackles noted on lung exam. workup was remarkable for hemoglobin 11.0g/dL, D-dimer 494.0 ng/mL, and elevated
transaminases. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the chest showed no pulmonary embolism, new diffuse
bilateral ground-glass opacities, and improved right upper lobe cavitary mass compared to CTA from three months ago.
Ceftriaxone and azithromycin were started for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia. Due to her symptoms and
image findings, she underwent bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) to test for atypical microorganisms.
Further workup showed elevated LDH 352 UI/L, elevated serum $-D-Glucan 388 pg/mL, positive P. jirovecii PCR from BAL,
and no acid-fast bacilli on smear. She was started on trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) with the improvement of
symptoms, in addition to tapering doses of steroids due to the degree of hypoxia. She was eventually discharged home to
complete a 21-day course of TMP/SMX and a steroid taper. PJP prophylaxis was recommended if she were to need further
chemotherapy.

DISCUSSION: Patients with PJP and malignant diseases have a shorter duration, more severe hypoxia, and poorer
prognosis. Only a few cases of PJP during DDC have been reported. While AC regimen is associated with lymphocyte
depletion, Paclitaxel has not been associated with such side effects. Daily corticosteroids have been used in the prevention
and treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, which has increased the risk for PJP. A recent study has
shown that intermittent corticosteroids as part of chemotherapy regimen could be a risk factor for developing PCP.

CONCLUSIONS: PJP is a rare but potentially fatal complication of early breast cancer (EBC) treatment. PJP should be suspected
in patients with EBC on DDC and intermittent doses of steroids. Further studies are needed to clarify whether providing PJP
prophylaxis and reducing the dose of intermittent steroids helps reduce the risks of PJP.

Reference #1: Sepkowitz KA. Opportunistic infections in patients with and patients without Acquired Immunodeficiency
Syndrome. Clin Infect Dis. 2002 Apr 15;34(8):1098-107. doi: 10.1086/339548. Epub 2002 Mar 21. Erratum in: Clin Infect Dis 2002
May 1;34(9):1293. PMID: 11914999.

Reference #2: Waks AG, Tolaney SM, Galar A, Arnaout A, Porter JB, Marty FM, Winer EP, Hammond SP, Baden LR.
Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP) in patients receiving neoadjuvant and adjuvant anthracycline-based chemotherapy for
breast cancer: incidence and risk factors. Breast Cancer Res Treat. 2015 Nov;154(2):359-67. doi: 10.1007/s10549-015-3573-2. Epub
2015 Sep 29. PMID: 26420402.

Reference #3: Calero-Bernal ML, Martin-Garrido I, Donazar-Ezcurra M, Limper AH, Carmona EM. Intermittent Courses of
Corticosteroids Also Present a Risk for Pneumocystis Pneumonia in Non-HIV Patients. Can Respir J. 2016;2016:2464791. doi:
10.1155/2016/2464791. Epub 2016 Sep 18. PMID: 27721666; PMCID: PMC5046011.

DISCLOSURES: No relevant relationships by Katherine Acosta
No relevant relationships by Ali Al Safi
